posts.html:
In this article, I’m going to walk you through building a series of Spring Boot microservices, and connect them together with Vyne.

Vyne is an intelligent orchestration engine, which automates the interaction between microservices to achieve goals & perform tasks.

This is an in-depth walkthrough from zero-to-hero. If you’re looking for something quick to get an understanding of Vyne, take a look at our interactive guide. Or, our docs might be more your pace if you want to explore the breadth of Vyne.

Throughout this article, we’ll touch on:

  • Zero-code orchestration to connect our services
  • Explore how our integration remains resilient to breaking API changes
  • Explore how Vyne leverages services to problem solve when integrating
  • See how our application evolves as new services appear

This article is long, and it covers everything from no knowledge of Vyne, to a fully working application. If you enjoy bite-sized chunks, most of these concepts are explored in Vyne’s walkthroughs in the docs.

And, if you’re more of a “Show me the code” type, then you can grab the code directly from this gitlab repo.

Our Application

We’re going to build a simple trade compliance application:

Our user — Kevin T. Trader, will enter details of a trade for one of his clients, and the panel will tell him if he’s compliant against a number of different rules.

Each of our rules takes a different set of data, with different constraints. We’ll see how Vyne gathers the necessary data, from various services, and invokes the rules engines.

Our Tech Stack

Here’s what we’ll be building on:

  • Spring Boot 2
  • Kotlin
  • Angular 7
  • Vyne
  • Eureka

Let’s get started

Step One: Starting the Vyne Server

First, we’ll deploy and start our Vyne query server.

Our services will register themselves with Vyne, to describe their schemas. To keep things simple, we’ll also start Vyne’s embedded Eureka instance, which will run as our service discovery client. This is optional, but reduces some of the config we’ll need.

docker run -e PROFILE='embedded-discovery' -p 9022:9022 vyneco/vyne

Now, navigate to http://localhost:9022 and you should see Vyne running, and Eureka running at http://localhost:9022/eureka-ui

Step Two: Registering our first service with Vyne

Now let’s build our first Spring Boot application. 

Start with a parent pom.xml, which will hold all the boilerplate. Unfortunately, there’s a bit of noise with Maven, Kotlin and Kapt, so this is pretty verbose:

There’s certainly a lot going on there — but most of it is the default setup for Kotlin.

This section is of interest to us:

<execution>
    <id>kapt</id>
    <goals>
        <goal>kapt</goal>
    </goals>
    <configuration>
        <annotationProcessorPaths>
            <annotationProcessorPath>
                <groupId>lang.taxi</groupId>
                <artifactId>taxi-annotation-processor</artifactId>
                <version>${taxi.version}</version>
            </annotationProcessorPath>
        </annotationProcessorPaths>
    </configuration>
</execution>

This turns on the Taxi Annotation Processor for our code.

Sidebar: Understanding Taxi vs Vyne

Taxi is a language that’s used to describe our services & models. It’s similar to Swagger, but has additional features. 

The annotation processor allows us to capture @DataType annotations on type aliases, which are lost by Kotlin by default. 

They’re useful, and we’ll see how a bit later.

Back to our service…

Let’s get that sample service stood up.

Create a new module in our maven project, and call it

posts.title: Taxi vs Swagger / RAML
posts.html:
I was asked recently about the limitations of Swagger et al that had encouraged me to write Taxi.

I think it’s a great question, and one that warrants a detailed answer. Both Swagger & RAML are obvious influences into the design of Taxi. I’ve been a big proponent, heavy user, & OSS contributor around Swagger for a number of years. They’re great tools, and I having a huge respect for them.

However, there are limitations that I’d hit which frustrated me as user of Swagger, and there are things I was trying to achieve when building Vyne that just weren’t possible with current tooling.

It’s worth mentioning that Swagger & RAML are both mature tools, whereas Taxi is sitting at v0.1. So, some of the goals outlined here indicate where we’re going, rather than where we are today.

Read & Writeability

Software is first & foremost a communication & storytelling medium. Good code is always measured by how well other people - not machines — are able to understand it.

Whether that’s through self documenting code, ubiquitous language, documentation hubs, BDD test suites, etc. Whatever techniques you choose to employ, the verdict is clear — The ability to capture, share and replay ideas between colleagues is a key factor in successful projects.

Swagger & RAML aren’t good communication formats for people — they’re simply too verbose. It’s a symptom of electing JSON & YAML as their languages — the content of the message gets lost in the noise of the syntax.

Look at these two snippets, both which communicate the same concept:

Through brevity, Taxi becomes more writable by hand — which, it turns out, is a key facet for promoting readability, and encourages using Taxi to exchange ideas.

Types as a documentation tool

Taxi also has microtypes as a first class concept — aliasing primitives with more descriptive names. This promotes embedding the UbiquitousLanguage directly within the DSL, and the language as a first class citizen within the type system.

Consider the same example, this time with Microtypes added in:

type Pet {
  id : PetId as Int
  name : Name as String
  tag : Tag as String
}

By leveraging microtypes, the rest of our API documentation becomes much clearer too:

operation findPet(String):Pet
// vs
operation findPet(Name):Pet

operation deletePet(Int)
// vs
operation deletePet(PetId)

Note that as Taxi is a documentation tool, (not a run-time), often we can omit parameter names in operations entirely, and the result is actually more readable.

It also has the benefit that tooling can now make smarter choices around what to provide to the deletePet() operation — not just any old Int will do, it needs to be a PetId.

Extensibility

API documentation exists to help consumers integrate. However, integration is a two-party party, and Swagger ignores one of those parties.

Swagger provides no way for consumers of an API to take the spec, and mix-in consumer specific information.

For example, dumping an object straight to a DB, using JPA — a fairly common task. Given our models are generated from the Swagger spec, it’d be nice as consumer to simply mix-in the annotations for JPA, and be done with it.

Sometimes, Swagger models are a boundary concern, and consumers will convert the inbound object to a type specific to the domain. When that adds value, it’s a sensible pattern to apply. However, if your domain model and the swagger type are the same, then that’s just pure duplication, without merit.

Taxi supports type extensions to fulfil this need, allowing consumers to mix in definitions that are meaningful to them:

type extension Pet {
   @Id id
}

The compiler / generator API is designed to allow plugins, so consumers can connect a JPA specific annotation processor, and bosh — JPA annotations on your generated model. Lovely.

Describing behaviour, not just existence.

Swagger and RAML describe the existence of operations— the address you can find a service at, and broadly what parameters you need to pass.

Taxi aims to go beyond, and describe the purpose of the operation — what happens when you call an operation, and what constraints must you satisfy before doing so.

// Constraints on inputs describe preconditions...
operation calculateCreditRisk(Money(currency = 'GBP')) : CreditRisk

// ...which others can then help satisfy:
operation convertCurrency(source : Money, target : Currency) : Money( from source,  currency = target )

This provides a model that tooling — such as Vyne — can use to understand how & when to call services, and how to chain services together to achieve goals.

The contract DSL is one of the most interesting aspects of Taxi, but it’s also fairly early in it’s implementation — I expect to see this evolve significantly over the coming months. I’m also watching with a keen eye how others in similar spaces are tackling the issue — Kotlin’s new Contracts DSL is really interesting.

Summary

Taxi is just getting going, but I think it offers real strengths over Swagger & RAML.

Strong interoperability with the existing tools is a design goal of Taxi. Ultimately, Taxi should exist as a superset of what’s expressible with Swagger.

Now’s a great time to provide feedback and input into the language as it evolves, to make sure we’re building a first-class DSL for describing API’s. We’ve just created our community over on Spectrum, so stop by and join the conversation.

posts.title: Going beyond Service Discovery with Capability Discovery
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[["soft-return","",{}]],"cards":[],"markups":[["strong"],["code"],["a"],["a",["href","https://vyne.co"]],["a",["href","https://stackedit.io/"]]],"sections":[[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Vyne: An Enterprise Data Mesh and Capability Concierge"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"With the meteoric rise of microservices,  existing service discovery approaches simply don't cut it anymore.  Three quarters of system development cost actually lies in the cost of integration.  Think about that -- for every week your organisation spends building services, you'll spend a further "],[0,[0],1,"three weeks"],[0,[],0," plumbing it all together."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"We think that's nuts."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"Service discovery isn’t a new idea, but it only goes part of the way towards realising true automated service integration."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"We built Vyne to address this, automating integration between your internal services, reducing the wasted time & effort in plumbing, and letting engineers stay productive."]]],[1,"h2",[[0,[],0,"Background"]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"As organisations began rolling out microservices, people pretty quickly realized that some sort of directory was needed – a “phonebook” where services would register and say, “I’m the customer details service” or “I’m the account balance service”, to allow services to find one another.. That “phonebook” would record the name and URL, removing the need to hardcode URLs for the services required."]]],[1,"p",[[0,[],0,"As those services moved or changed their address, the lookup functionality kept the different services talking to each other. And, importantly, as services started to scale up and there was more than one instance of a specific type of service, the complexities of load balancing - knowing which instance to talk to - was hidden away from the callers. posts.html:
Vyne: An Enterprise Data Mesh and Capability Concierge

With the meteoric rise of microservices,  existing service discovery approaches simply don't cut it anymore.  Three quarters of system development cost actually lies in the cost of integration.  Think about that -- for every week your organisation spends building services, you'll spend a further three weeks plumbing it all together.

We think that's nuts.

Service discovery isn’t a new idea, but it only goes part of the way towards realising true automated service integration.

We built Vyne to address this, automating integration between your internal services, reducing the wasted time & effort in plumbing, and letting engineers stay productive.

Background

As organisations began rolling out microservices, people pretty quickly realized that some sort of directory was needed – a “phonebook” where services would register and say, “I’m the customer details service” or “I’m the account balance service”, to allow services to find one another.. That “phonebook” would record the name and URL, removing the need to hardcode URLs for the services required.

As those services moved or changed their address, the lookup functionality kept the different services talking to each other. And, importantly, as services started to scale up and there was more than one instance of a specific type of service, the complexities of load balancing - knowing which instance to talk to - was hidden away from the callers. Zookeeper and Eureka and Consul were the first tranche of service-discovery services.

As organisations moved towards containerised infrastructure (such as Kubernetes or Docker Swarm) the role of Service Discovery was folded into the virtual network, resulting in a virtual DNS where you say “I want to call this service” and you end up with a network address that you can call, with services that sit behind that.

The limitations

Despite what the name suggests, this is not actually service discovery – it’s really just address lookup.

In order to actually get stuff done - for example look up customer information – engineers still have to do the (discovery) work of researching which service can give you that information.

This involves asking around the organisation to find the correct service and API to call, pulling the API into service code, and going through the documentation to understand the structure of the data you get back.

Tools like Mulesoft and API 'stores' gives a central hub to go and browse - but that's about it - the actual integration work is left to engineers.

So, while Service Discovery does a great job of abstracting away the URL of where services reside, the grunt work of actual discovery still has to be done, and embedding that API directly inside code leaves the two services tightly coupled.

Just Dial '0'

Let's pause for a moment, and consider the joys of staying on a hotel, trying to book tickets for a night at the theatre.   It's simple - dial 0, talk to the concierge and explain you'd like to see a musical. Ten minutes later there's a call to say a taxi will arrive at 7pm to take you to the theatre, where the tickets are reserved in your name at the box office.

How the concierge booked those tickets is entirely hidden from you. They may have had to visit five different individual theatre websites, or maybe logged on to Ticketek.com. It could be that a new theatre or a new show has opened, or possibly the concierge is on a mailing list of last minute ticket returns. You don’t need to know about any of that - the concierge is actually doing true discovery for you.

The world around the question evolves constantly, but as the person who’s asking, we don’t want to or need to know any of that. The basic need has been resolved by the concierge.

Similarly in software, we want to abstract ourselves away from the detail, to focus on Getting Stuff Done.  Consider a simple requirement -- given a customers' email address, re-order their last purchase.  However, this requires stitching together multiple different services,  to go from the customer email to customer number to last order made to name of the product(s) to the SKU, to a stock service that tells me if there’s any of those in stock.

Fundamentally, I don't care about the journey & hops required - I just want to get stuff done, and be abstracted away from the details.

You can't survive on Swagger alone.

Various tooling and languages have emerged to improve how we document and share APIs – but they don’t go far enough to address the inefficiencies of integration. Tools such as Swagger and RAML are great for describing an API, but fall short when it comes to describing capability.

For example, the Swagger contract for a service that takes in a customer ID and returns a customer name, is actually just described as taking a String and returning a String. It doesn’t describe what that service actually does, and there’s nothing that differentiates that contract from the contract that takes a postcode and gives you back a city name.

Without systems describing their capability, concierge services aren't possible -- and it ultimately falls back to a developer to read and understand the Swagger API, generate an SDK, and write, test and maintain the integration code.

This happens again and again for every different service they need to call in order to achieve their end goal.

Worse, much of this work happens repeatedly across the organisation; one developer needs to get from system A to system B, and two weeks later another developer in another team has to go through exactly the same loop.

Not only is this time consuming and wasteful, but the resulting code is fragile – when one part of the path changes, consumer’s plumbing code needs to adapt, or systems may break down.

The true cost of changing an API lies with consumers (who need to update their code). This means the most popular services are inherently the ones with the highest cost of change. This creates an inertia to change – it’s often just not worth the time and effort involved – and systems start to decay.

For every £1M spent on building software a further £2.8M will be spent integrating it
(Forrester  Research)

Forrester Research estimates that for every £1M spent to build the systems, £2.8M is spent integrating them. That means three quarters of the development work is the boring, repetitive plumbing tasks the developers don’t enjoy, which isn't core business, and does nothing to generate revenue.

What innovation might happen once you free up that significant developer resource? The question becomes “What can we do?” which is value-add, rather than “How do we do it?” which is value-drag.

Hello, Vyne: an enterprise data mesh and service concierge

Vyne turns your existing microservices into a Data Mesh, automating integration between your services.  Think of Vyne as your digital concierge - there to help you get stuff done.

As we've talked about before, we  addressed the shortfall in tools like Swagger and RAML, by building tooling that allows services to describe the actual capabilities they offer – not just their schemas.

Services register with Vyne – just like they would with service discovery – and publish the capabilities they offer. Vyne uses this information to build a mesh of the capabilities of all of your services.

Then, instead of developers building point-to-point integration solutions, consumers send their requests to Vyne, in a form of “Given this thing I know, here’s what I’d like to do / like to discover”.

Vyne acts as an intelligent API Gateway, and uses its knowledge of the service mesh to orchestrate an automated “Just-in-time” integration plan – calling the right services to discover the right data, and passing information from service-to-service, to perform the required task.

Vyne can apply intelligent problem solving along the route – understanding when data is missing, in the wrong format, or some other contract hasn’t been satisfied – and attempts to find other services to address the issue.

Finally, because the consumer code is entirely decoupled from the services and contracts that it calls, the cost and friction of change is significantly reduced. Vyne’s integration plans automatically adapt as services evolve, without consumers needing to change their code.

Automating the plumbing makes for happier developers, lower development costs, and integrated systems that are robust, adaptable and optimally serve the needs of the business. All good news.

Contact us for a demo to learn how to evolve your API strategy with Vyne: hello@vyne.co.

Or, head over to https://vyne.co to get started now.

Written with StackEdit.

posts.html:
I’m happy to announce that we’ve shipped version 0.1 of Taxi — which is a huge part of what powers Vyne’s integration engine.

Taxi is a DSL for describing API’s — specifically the operations they perform, and the models they return. It has a compiler for validation of models, and a powerful generation tools — for generating Taxi from source, and generating source from taxi.

The source is here, and the docs are here. (including a nice Getting Started guide)

Taxi is designed with readability in mind — Taxi documents are really easy to understand. And, although most Taxi code will be generated, it’s quite easy (and natural) to craft a Taxi document by hand.

It’s also designed to be extensible. Different teams will consume data from API’s in different ways — Taxi supports this by allowing consumers to mix in their own annotations or refinements at generation time.

Services can describe not just how to call them, but what functionality they provide, and what constraints must be satisfied to call them.

How Taxi powers Vyne

Vyne is a tool for automating integration between services. It uses metadata published by services to understand what functionality they can provide, and how to interact with them.

To facilitate this, we needed a language that could express this information for Vyne to read — Swagger lacked the constructs we needed.

Also, we wanted something that was readable — there’s a lot of metadata to consume, and grokking through lengthy RAML documents is pretty unappealing.

So, we built Taxi.

Internally, all metadata about services is mapped using Taxi. (Note, Vyne can consume other document types, like Swagger and RAML, however these are converted to Taxi). This model is fed into our integration engine to build integrations on demand.

Prior art & Roadmap

Taxi takes heavy inspiration from Swagger and RAML, and intends to grow to become a superset of the features supported by those languages (and there’s already support for converting Swagger to Taxi).

However, as a dedicated DSL, Taxi is much more readable than either Swagger or RAML. Also, Taxi isn’t coupled to HTTP / RESTful API’s. We’re starting there, but plan on expanding to supporting streaming based API’s from MQ’s or Websocket APIs, which are rapidly becoming first-class citizens in modern applications.

What’s been shipped today is very much a 0.1 release. Taxi is used heavily within Vyne, but as a standalone tool, it’s still in its infancy. However, we’re releasing this early, to try and build discipline around shipping early.

Our generator tooling is built to provide a framework for others to extend upon. The tooling for both generating Taxi from sources, and for generating source from Taxi is built with plugins and extensibility in mind. We’ve shipped generators for going to-and-from Kotlin — but the API’s make adding other languages simple — in fact the entire Kotlin generator only took a morning to build.

There’s an API for consuming annotations when generating code — although we haven’t shipped any public facing consumers of this yet, but JPA annotation wrappers will be coming shortly.

In addition to building out our own generators, we’ll shortly be launching a hub for sharing of extensions, to encourage a developer ecosystem to build around Taxi.

Finally, there’s a tonne of documentation that’s been written on using Taxi.

In the upcoming releases, we’ll be focussing on improving developer usability of the Taxi tooling, adding support for additional languages, and further expanding the docs and use cases.

posts.html:
Vyne is a new tool for automating integration between services.

Vyne’s goal is to replace brittle, hand-written integration code with automated, adaptive integrations, wrapped in a beautiful declarative API.

Motivation

As companies embrace microservices and serverless / lambda based architectures, the catalog of services and endpoints internally available is growing rapidly. The holy grail of microservices was always many small independent teams operating freely, spinning up new services, releasing and iterating with ease.

However, services — and therefore the teams that publish them — must work together to generate value. Each new service that appears provides functionality for others to consume —requiring developers to write integration code, fetching data and performing actions.

These integrations are often brittle & time consuming, and as new versions emerge, existing integration code must be upgraded to match. This requires co-ordination and planning, leading to lingering deprecated API’s that can’t be removed until all teams are upgraded.

Tooling has emerged which assists with parts of this — 
Service Discovery platforms like Eureka and Consul provide a live address book of where services are deployed.
Swagger / OpenAPI have helped provide living documentation of what functions services can perform, and what inputs they need to do so. And tools like GraphQL and JSON-LD have emerged to encourage developers to think of their data as a graph of connected entities.

However, while these tools aid in improving discoverability and reducing boilerplate, they all still depend on developers reading the docs, and connecting the services manually. Even though your “User” service has a Swagger API, and is registered with service discovery, existing tooling is unable to know when it needs a “User”, how to leverage existing data, and then invoke your service. This is where Vyne comes in.

Vyne borrows from and builds upon these technologies, focusing on enabling autonomous integration between services.

Vyne — Automated, adaptive integration

Vyne has a simple, expressive API, that lets you express integrations as you would naturally:
 “Given [something I know], discover [something else]”

Vyne then leverages services & their metadata to find a way to perform your integration task.

Vyne knows about the services that are deployed across your enterprise — it knows what services exist, how to invoke them, and what functionality they provide. 
It can construct request objects, discover missing input values from other services, and use services to transform data between formats. Vyne is agnostic to the underlying protocols — JSON over REST / SOAP / gRPC / Protobufs are all covered. Support for streaming and async interactions is on the roadmap too.

And, as the underlying services evolve and upgrade their API’s, Vyne automatically adapts it’s solution to suit — no developer cycles required. This means that changes to services are much less likely to be breaking, reducing the friction & co-ordination required in release cycles, and allowing developers to focus on releasing functionality, rather than maintaining deprecated API’s.

Vyne leads to code that is both dramatically simpler, and signficiantly more resilliant to change. The following two pieces of code perform the same task — manually, and then on the right, with Vyne. The difference is clear.

In addition, Vyne has some powerful developer and monitoring tooling, to help visualise what solutions Vyne is using for integration tasks.

The below diagram, which was generated from the Vyne developer app — shows the solution from a Bank trade compliance app, where Vyne was used to discover a JurisdictionRuleResponse for a given trade.
Vyne needed to construct a specific request object — and to do so, needed to discover two additional values — A ClientJurisdiction and TraderJurisdiction.

Where can I get it?

Vyne is still in it’s early stages. The first mileston release — 0.1, is coming soon, which provides an MVP of basic functionality. There’s an exciting roadmap of functionality planned out, on the way to a 1.0 release.

If you’re interested in leveraging Vyne to reduce the pain of integration, I’d love to hear from you — drop me a line at marty@vyne.co.

posts.html:
Part I: Everything sucks

Technology organisations have adopted APIs at the heart of their IT strategy. However, with teams moving faster than ever, and microservices on the rise, the number of integration touchpoints is exploding.  Our current patterns of API consumption simply don't cut it.

Distribute information, not APIs

Organisations don't really want APIs - they want easy access to information and capability. APIs are really just a means to an end.

On one hand, the tooling for publishing APIs to make data and services accessible has matured massively - it's never been easier to simply expose a RESTful endpoint, documented with Swagger, Gitops'd out to your fancy elastic Kubernetes cluster.  Boom...check... APIs delivered, right?  Wrong.

While we've managed to commoditize the process of publishing APIs, sadly the overhead of consuming APIs is crippling. The reality is that most API strategies today put too much cost on the consumer:

  • The cost of discovery - finding the right API which serves the data you're looking for in a large organisation can be tough
  • The cost of integration - The initial build out of integration takes time.  OpenAPI tooling helps, but it's wins are very short-lived.
  • The cost of maintenance - The silent killer.  As producers change their APIs, this burden of change flows downstream to all consumers.

The worst part of consumer facing costs are they are repeated - integrating APIs is a tax that dev teams pays repeatedly in order to get and retain access to information.

Organisations with internal API strategies are paying this tax over and over, for every new consumer that spins up.

...Integrating APIs is a tax that dev teams pays repeatedly in order to get and retain access to information.

This high cost of change leads to a paradox of success - the more consumers an API has, the higher the number of points to change, meaning the more expensive it is to evolve.  As a result, some services simply become too critical to evolve, and their unmaintained APIs continue to spread - like a forgotten ham sandwich in the bottom of  kids schoolbag.

Swagger is not a (consumer) strategy

Swagger/OpenAPI - and their newest incarnation, Service Catalogues - are great tools.  However, the traditional adoption patterns in using OpenAPI results in building horribly brittle architectures.  Swagger's "SDKs for APIs" is really just tooling that helps tightly couple interfaces across the enterprise.

Whether you're using OpenAPI codegen tools, service catalogues to help find APIs, or UI based drag-and-drop integrators, these are all tools that facilitate tight coupling between consumers and producers.  As a result, whenever upstream APIs change, consumers are obligated to update along with them.

Swagger/OpenAPI - and their newest incarnation, Service Catalogues - are great tools for building horribly brittle architectures.

That's not to say that OpenAPI documentation isn't great - it is.  So is Protobuf,  gRPC, GraphQL - even WSDLs for that matter ... we need more, richer, better API documentation.  (Heck, that's why we built Taxi)

And, API publishers should be held accountable for producing accurate detailed API docs, in a machine readable format. (README.md and whatever Wiki software exists in your enterprise doesn't count).

But, our thinking around consumer patterns needs to evolve beyond expecting consumers to hitch their wagon to whatever producers publish.

Put simply, today's API consumer patterns facilitate rapidly producing tightly coupled services.  That's clearly nuts.

Consumers want information.  APIs are a producers concern - and one we should abstract away from.

Consumers just need access to information - they shouldn't have to care about the mechanics of APIs.  Really, a consumer just needs to define two things:

  • Defining the data they want
  • Defining the shape they want it

Everything outside of this is an implementation concern - and one that we should be abstracting consumers away from.

If a producer has done a good enough job of documenting their APIs - the data they expose and their "rules of engagement" - then software should be handling the API interaction.  

Consumer patterns need to evolve towards a dynamic knowledge broker that facilitates delivering data, as the consumer needs it, without coupling consumers and producers together. (Spoiler alert: this is what we build, but I'll come back to that).

Producers should be free to evolve their APIs without worrying about the cascading change of all their consumers.  After all - that's what microservices and Agile practices promised, right - small, autonomous teams iterating and delivering at pace.  Instead, what we got was a mess of integration code and change committees to ensure releases don't break consumers.

...[we need] a dynamic knowledge broker that facilitates delivering data, as the consumer needs it, without coupling consumers and producers together.

Federated GraphQL isn't the answer either

Thoughtworks recently phrased this beautifully - GraphQL is certainly "having it's moment".  

GraphQL was designed as a tool for reducing HTTP traffic for Web traffic to a backend, and cherry-picking data attributes from a predefined domain model.  And, for this purpose, it really is a remarkable tool.  

However, GraphQL was never intended as a back-end federation strategy. And, while it seems some tools are pushing in this direction, it's a much less compelling offering.

Importantly, different services across an enterprise have different data domain models - and that's a Good Thing - teams should be free to express ideas in ways that are meaningful to them, regardless of duplication.  GraphQL doesn't try to solve this problem.

And while GraphQL does allow consumers to opt-out of the data they don't care about, accessing new data, or data in a different shape still incurs an integration tax that adds no value.

Globally shared domain models - whether that's a GraphQL schema, or an "Enterprise Domain Model" - is not an effective knowledge distribution strategy:  

  • It restricts how information can be distributed - limiting only to what the schema can express.
  • It requires that all consumers consume data in the same shape.  Attempting to feed data downstream to another?  You're out of luck, it's a one-size-fits-all policy around here, bub.
  • It ultimately results in a (deferred) cascading change, when the schema ultimately needs to evolve.

Summary

APIs are great, if you're a producer.  But consumer patterns haven't evolved, and today lead to tightly coupled services.

Enterprises need new middleware knowledge brokers, that facilitate discovery of data, without tightly coupling producers and consumers, and without incurring the massive integration tax.

In our next post, we'll talk about how to achieve this, using Vyne.

It's been a while since we've posted to the blog.  But we've been very busy.

2020 was an amazing year for the Vyne team.  We grew from being an idea to a production platform, deployed in heart of some of the worlds biggest API and data strategies.

  • 84 releases of Vyne.  At the time of writing, we're on 0.13.6, but will have probably released again by the time you read this.  
  • Taxi grew up too - with 45 new releases, containing some really amazing language features and command line tooling
  • A Visual Studio Code plugin for Taxi, which provides syntax checking, as you type compilation, and all sorts of editor goodness

What's new in Vyne?

So, what did we actually ship in those 84 releases?   In addition to a bunch of bug fixes, here's some of the highlights:

Vyne Casks

Casks provide a rapid way to make offline data available with a RESTful API, and then

These deserve their own blog post, which we'll be publishing shortly.

We released 84 new versions of Vyne last year.  At the time of writing, we're on

{"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["markdown",{"markdown":"
In my [previous post](/rethinking-api-consumer-patterns/), I outlined the challenges with current practices for consuming APIs within an enterprise - finding the right information amongst a sea of API endpoints, and protecting consumers from fragility from change by producers.

In this post, we'll explore how by doing a better job of describing the "what" within our APIs, we can offload all the integration work to a broker, who can do all the information gathering for us.

This idea of an information broker is what [Vyne](https://vyne.co) does, dynamically discovering information and automating integration between services.  

If you're interested in skipping straight to the reveal, you can simply watch the demo video here, and then circle back to read about the principals on show.

## API brokers - A concierge for your data
Introducing a broker that sits between API services and their consumers creates a lot of flexibility.  If a broker understands the suite of services available and what they offer, we can reduce the amount of knowledge that consumers need to have.

![blog-images](/content/images/2021/01/blog-images.png)

Rather than consumers becoming coupled to every API that provides the data they need, they can simply ask the broker for the information, and let it do the work - like asking a hotel concierge for local information.

![blog-images--1-](/content/images/2021/01/blog-images--1-.png)

GraphQL is a great example of this idea in action - providing a single API entrypoint, that acts as a facade to multiple back-end services.  (We love GraphQL, but think that it doesn't go far enough in decoupling - more on that later).

To work well, a broker should:

- **Allow consumers to discover information without becoming coupled to the producers**
- **Allow consumers to ask for data in a shape that's meaningful to them.**
  This whole affair is pointless if the first step consumers take is to map fetched data into another object.  
  Since we've already decoupled the producers and consumers, let's allow the consumer to simply request it's own domain object, removing the additional mapping step entirely.
- **Adapt to change automatically.**
  As producers evolve, integrations should automatically adapt.  After all, "automation" that requires manual updates on every change isn't automation, it's work-shifting. 

>  ..."automation" that requires manual updates on every change isn't automation, it's work-shifting. 

To do this:

- We'd need a shared way for producers and consumers to describe data and capability, without requiring a global shared domain model
- Schema information needs to be rich enough that the API broker can automatically determine which service (or services) to call in order to satisfy a request

## Integrate information, don't glue labels

The key piece to making this work is how we describe and integrate information between systems.  

Most integration approaches boil down to linking labels in maps - connecting the key of one key/value pair from within some nested maps to the label of another.   

Layer on as many fancy Integration Builder UI's, swagger-generated SDK's or GraphQL resolvers as you like - peel back the layers, and it's still just labels 'n' glue.  Rename those labels, and the whole thing just falls apart.

![blog-images--2-](/content/images/2021/01/blog-images--2-.png)

Not only is this really brittle, it's a really error-prone approach - schemas tend to lack sufficient detail to do this label matching unambiguously - so we fall back to inline comments and wiki pages to explain which field to use in which circumstance.  While documentation is better than nothing, it's not something we can leverage for automation.

Ironically, API authors will debate for hours on whether to use JSON or YAML for their Swagger schema, PUT vs POST, how to capitalise words, to indent with tabs or spaces, and how many.  But disambiguating which string represents the buyer and seller in a transaction?  Pfft! Someone else will work that out.

>  API authors will debate for hours on whether to use JSON or YAML for their Swagger schema, PUT vs POST, spaces vs tabs, etc.  
>  
>  But clarifying which string represents the buyer and seller in a transaction?  Pfft! Someone else will work that out.

### ***What*** matters.

> Data models actually represent two contracts - What and Where

Part of the challenge here is that data models have two contracts - **what** data you'll find, and **where** to find it.

For example:

* "You'll find the number we use to identify the customer..." (what)
* "...in a field called `id`" (where)

Generally speaking, API schemas focus almost exclusively on documenting structure, and do a terrible job of describing *what* information they actually contain - simply describing everything as a bunch of `String`, `Integer` and `Boolean` values.

> API Schemas are great a telling you ***where*** to find stuff, but <u>terrible</u> at describing ***what*** you'll find there.

![blog-images--3-](/content/images/2021/01/blog-images--3-.png)

However, because we have no unambiguous, cross-system way of saying "This is the Customer Number", we fall back using labels - like a poor co-ordinates system: "Read the word customer, and then the word id and there you shall find your answer."

If our schemas could do a better job of describing what information they hold, then both discovery of information and mapping content between systems becomes much more automatable. We can simply read the `CustomerId`, regardless of whether a system used the label `id`, `CustomerId`, `custId`, or `Customer`.


#### Sharing models:  Ew, David. Gross.
We also need to be careful not to head down the path of enterprise shared models - those don't work.  

Constraining independent systems to use shared contracts makes change really hard.  Also, it doesn't actually save any time - You're just left with more mapping layers - the "shared model" gets mapped to the internal domain model, simply moving the work.  

These mapping layers result in the kind of low-value busywork they're designed to prevent, and that we're trying to avoid.

> Globally shared models create the type of low-value mapping busywork they're designed to prevent, and that we're trying so hard to avoid.


### Two roles of schema: Structure and Content

It turns out there's actually two different types of contract present within our schemas - structure and content.

Strutcural contracts are useful to tell systems where to find...something, but as we've seen, they do little to describe what information you'll find there.

We need a better way of describing the content in each field.  As it turns out, software systems have *great* mechanisms for categorising information - Types.

By Types, I don't mean primitives like `String`, `Integer` (we're already using those, and it's not working).  I mean a creating something richer - more aligned to the business vocabulary - a shared set of semantic terms, and building a type system around them: `FirstName`, `LastName`, `CustomerId`.

Once we model content, independent of structure, we can start matching on things that share meaning, regardless of what they're called:

![blog-images--5-](/content/images/2021/01/blog-images--5-.png)

In order to avoid falling into the "shared model" trap, Types need to be so small, that they describe content, but without requiring structure.  Small and simple - attributes with a Single Responsibility.

More specifically in this paradigm, Types should be Scalar - ideas that can be represented without attributes.  As soon as a Type adopts attributes - it starts modelling both meaning and structure - so is actually likely multiple ideas mixed together.  This keeps types related to a single idea - a single word in our shared vocabulary.

Of course, a shared vocabulary in software isn't a new idea - agile practitioners have long advocated for a Ubiquitous Language.  All we're suggesting is making this vocabulary a first-class citizen of API documentation and tooling.  

> Agile practitioners have long advocated for a Ubiquitous Language - all we're suggesting is making this a first-class citizen of API documentation and tooling.  

These ideas of semantic types aren't new either - and while similar toolsets such as RDF / OWL / JSON-LD have been around for some time, their learning curve have prevented adoption.  Therefore, it's important that whatever we build must be simple, readable, and writable.

By building out a rich language of simple Types, we get the building blocks to describe our API models with, and giving us two distinct concepts within our schema space - Types (describing the "What") and Models (describing the structure).

Let's define those a little more formally:

#### Types
Types represent a single atom of information - a set of shared business concepts used to exchange information - such as `FirstName`, `LastName`, `CustomerId`, `DateOfBirth`, etc.   We've found that once defined, these don't change very frequently.  

Types are scalar (attribute-free), single purpose, and seldom change, making them good candidates for sharing.  Types are owned and curated collectively, and while (at the beginning) new terms emerge fairly frequently, changes to definitions are less common.

#### Models
Models are owned by individual systems (the ones that produce the model), and evolve rapidly.  Composed of types, they are reshaped, tweaked, with information added and removed frequently - changing with pace as teams ship and refactor functionality.  Models describe their attributes using types from the shared taxonomy.

Having introduced these two key building blocks, let talk about the tooling we built to support this idea.


## Using Taxi to describe, and Vyne to discover

We built [Taxi](https://docs.taxilang.org) to address the semantic gap in the schema toolchain - a way to build a semantic taxonomy, and apply it to APIs.  

Taxi can work either as a stand-alone API schema, or to decorate existing API Schemas, overlaying semantic context.  This means you don't have to throw away all your swagger, you can just mix in some taxi.

Taxi's goals are human readability, descriptiveness, and extensibility.  You can write Taxi by hand (unlike Swagger), or generate it from code.  Taxi is [open-source](https://gitlab.com/taxi-lang/taxi-lang), type-safe and functionally rich. 

Because it's a custom built language, Taxi is much easier to read than Swagger or RAML, which have been shoe-horned into JSON and YAML.  

Taxi's syntax borrows heavily from languages like Typescript and Kotlin, which have gained adoption in large part because they're designed to be approachable.  We think this is a big difference against other languages in this space, such as JSON-LD, OWL or RDF, which have a much higher barrier-to-entry.

Let's explore how adding some semantic sugar to our API might look.

First, let's define some Types and Models:

```typescript
type FirstName inherits String
type LastName inherits String
type CustomerId inherits Int
type EmailAddress inherits String
type PrimaryEmailAddress inherits EmailAddress

model Customer {
  firstName : FirstName
  lastName : LastName
  email : PrimaryEmailAddress
  secondaryEmail : EmailAddress
  customerId : CustomerId	
}
```

And finally, a microservice that's using these:

```typescript
service CustomerService {
  @HttpOperation(method="GET", url="http://customers/{id}")
  operation getCustomer(id: CustomerId):Customer
}
```

Given this description, it quickly becomes apparent that if I know a `CustomerId`, I can get a `Customer`.  And, if I have a `Customer`, I have access to a bunch of information about them, like their `FirstName`, and `PrimaryEmailAddress`.  

At this point, the data is sufficiently described that someone can ask for data, agnostic of the service providing it, or the shape it comes in.  

For example, as a consumer of data, I could simply ask it something like:

```typescript
given {
  id : CustomerId = 123
} find {
  name : FirstName
  emails: {
    primary: PrimaryEmailAddress
  }
}
```

As a consumer request, I've outlined both the semantic contract, and the structural contract I'd like satisfied here.  However, I haven't talked about services at all - as a consumer, they're not really of concern to me.

There's enough information for a broker to leverage this, and invoke the correct service to satisfy my request.

Or, if I need my data in a different structure, I can simply ask:

```typescript
given {
  customerId: CustomerId = 123
} find {
  name: FirstName + ' ' + LastName // Taxi supports basic operations
  contactDetails : {
    preferredEmail : PrimaryEmailAddress
    // allEmails would contain both "email" and "secondaryEmail", since they're both of type EmailAddress
    allEmails : EmailAddress[] 
  }
}
```

It's entirely up to the consumer to determine the shape of the data they want.  

Since we've decoupled the structure from the content, there's enough information for a broker to leverage find and construct the object, without having to maintain a manual mapping layer for every attribute.

> By describing both structure and content in the schema, there's enough information for a broker to find and construct an object, without having to maintain a mapping for every attribute.


This is where [Vyne](https://vyne.co) comes in.  Vyne is our discovery engine - capable of understanding semantic schemas, and leveraging that information to automatically discover data.


### Inter-service orchestration

Since our services now have a shared language for describing inputs and outputs (decoupled from structure), we can even leverage this to push inter-service orchestration up to Vyne.

Let's add another service into the mix:

```typescript
type AcceptsMarketingEmails inherits Boolean
type AllowsCookieTracking inherits Boolean

model MarketingPreferences {
  emailAddress : EmailAddress
  cookies : AllowsCookieTracking
  marketingEmails : AcceptsMarketingEmails
}

service MarketingService {
  @HttpOperation(method="GET", url="http://marketingPreferences/{emailAddress}")
  operation getMarketingPreferences(emailAddress:PrimaryEmailAddress):MarketingPreferences
}
```

We now have a separate producer microservice that's exposing information about marketing preferences.

As a consumer, I can request data, agnostic of where it's coming from:

```typescript
given {
  id : CustomerId = 123
} find {
  // Provided by our original CustomerService
  name : FirstName 
  
  // Provided by our original CustomerService
  emailAddress : PrimaryEmailAddress 
  
  // Provided by the new MarketingService
  canSendMarketingEmails : AcceptsMarketingEmails 
}
```

There's enough breadcrumbs to build a path:

```
Original CustomerId -> CustomerRecord -> PrimaryEmailAddress -> MarketingPreferences
```

// TODO : Replace the above with a lineage screenshot from Vyne.

We're able to see here that Vyne was able to bridge multiple services, automatically passing data from one to the next.

## Summary

Structure and Semantics are two different types of contracts, and most API schemas at the moment fail to model semantics in a meaningful way.  

By creating a taxonomy of shared terms, and overlaying this taxonomy onto our schemas, we have enough information for tools such as Vyne to perform rich, complex data discovery operations.

Finally, by decoupling consumers from both producer services and structural contracts, the producers are free to evolve and change at will, without forcing consumers to upgrade.

posts.html:
In my previous post, I outlined the challenges with current practices for consuming APIs within an enterprise - finding the right information amongst a sea of API endpoints, and protecting consumers from fragility from change by producers.

In this post, we'll explore how by doing a better job of describing the "what" within our APIs, we can offload all the integration work to a broker, who can do all the information gathering for us.

This idea of an information broker is what Vyne does, dynamically discovering information and automating integration between services.

If you're interested in skipping straight to the reveal, you can simply watch the demo video here, and then circle back to read about the principals on show.

API brokers - A concierge for your data

Introducing a broker that sits between API services and their consumers creates a lot of flexibility. If a broker understands the suite of services available and what they offer, we can reduce the amount of knowledge that consumers need to have.

Rather than consumers becoming coupled to every API that provides the data they need, they can simply ask the broker for the information, and let it do the work - like asking a hotel concierge for local information.

GraphQL is a great example of this idea in action - providing a single API entrypoint, that acts as a facade to multiple back-end services. (We love GraphQL, but think that it doesn't go far enough in decoupling - more on that later).

To work well, a broker should:

  • Allow consumers to discover information without becoming coupled to the producers
  • Allow consumers to ask for data in a shape that's meaningful to them.
    This whole affair is pointless if the first step consumers take is to map fetched data into another object.
    Since we've already decoupled the producers and consumers, let's allow the consumer to simply request it's own domain object, removing the additional mapping step entirely.
  • Adapt to change automatically.
    As producers evolve, integrations should automatically adapt. After all, "automation" that requires manual updates on every change isn't automation, it's work-shifting.

..."automation" that requires manual updates on every change isn't automation, it's work-shifting.

To do this:

  • We'd need a shared way for producers and consumers to describe data and capability, without requiring a global shared domain model
  • Schema information needs to be rich enough that the API broker can automatically determine which service (or services) to call in order to satisfy a request

Integrate information, don't glue labels

The key piece to making this work is how we describe and integrate information between systems.

Most integration approaches boil down to linking labels in maps - connecting the key of one key/value pair from within some nested maps to the label of another.

Layer on as many fancy Integration Builder UI's, swagger-generated SDK's or GraphQL resolvers as you like - peel back the layers, and it's still just labels 'n' glue. Rename those labels, and the whole thing just falls apart.

Not only is this really brittle, it's a really error-prone approach - schemas tend to lack sufficient detail to do this label matching unambiguously - so we fall back to inline comments and wiki pages to explain which field to use in which circumstance. While documentation is better than nothing, it's not something we can leverage for automation.

Ironically, API authors will debate for hours on whether to use JSON or YAML for their Swagger schema, PUT vs POST, how to capitalise words, to indent with tabs or spaces, and how many. But disambiguating which string represents the buyer and seller in a transaction? Pfft! Someone else will work that out.

API authors will debate for hours on whether to use JSON or YAML for their Swagger schema, PUT vs POST, spaces vs tabs, etc.

But clarifying which string represents the buyer and seller in a transaction? Pfft! Someone else will work that out.

What matters.

Data models actually represent two contracts - What and Where

Part of the challenge here is that data models have two contracts - what data you'll find, and where to find it.

For example:

  • "You'll find the number we use to identify the customer..." (what)
  • "...in a field called id" (where)

Generally speaking, API schemas focus almost exclusively on documenting structure, and do a terrible job of describing what information they actually contain - simply describing everything as a bunch of String, Integer and Boolean values.

API Schemas are great a telling you where to find stuff, but terrible at describing what you'll find there.

However, because we have no unambiguous, cross-system way of saying "This is the Customer Number", we fall back using labels - like a poor co-ordinates system: "Read the word customer, and then the word id and there you shall find your answer."

If our schemas could do a better job of describing what information they hold, then both discovery of information and mapping content between systems becomes much more automatable. We can simply read the CustomerId, regardless of whether a system used the label id, CustomerId, custId, or Customer.

Sharing models: Ew, David. Gross.

We also need to be careful not to head down the path of enterprise shared models - those don't work.

Constraining independent systems to use shared contracts makes change really hard. Also, it doesn't actually save any time - You're just left with more mapping layers - the "shared model" gets mapped to the internal domain model, simply moving the work.

These mapping layers result in the kind of low-value busywork they're designed to prevent, and that we're trying to avoid.

Globally shared models create the type of low-value mapping busywork they're designed to prevent, and that we're trying so hard to avoid.

Two roles of schema: Structure and Content

It turns out there's actually two different types of contract present within our schemas - structure and content.

Strutcural contracts are useful to tell systems where to find...something, but as we've seen, they do little to describe what information you'll find there.

We need a better way of describing the content in each field. As it turns out, software systems have great mechanisms for categorising information - Types.

By Types, I don't mean primitives like String, Integer (we're already using those, and it's not working). I mean a creating something richer - more aligned to the business vocabulary - a shared set of semantic terms, and building a type system around them: FirstName, LastName, CustomerId.

Once we model content, independent of structure, we can start matching on things that share meaning, regardless of what they're called:

In order to avoid falling into the "shared model" trap, Types need to be so small, that they describe content, but without requiring structure. Small and simple - attributes with a Single Responsibility.

More specifically in this paradigm, Types should be Scalar - ideas that can be represented without attributes. As soon as a Type adopts attributes - it starts modelling both meaning and structure - so is actually likely multiple ideas mixed together. This keeps types related to a single idea - a single word in our shared vocabulary.

Of course, a shared vocabulary in software isn't a new idea - agile practitioners have long advocated for a Ubiquitous Language. All we're suggesting is making this vocabulary a first-class citizen of API documentation and tooling.

Agile practitioners have long advocated for a Ubiquitous Language - all we're suggesting is making this a first-class citizen of API documentation and tooling.

These ideas of semantic types aren't new either - and while similar toolsets such as RDF / OWL / JSON-LD have been around for some time, their learning curve have prevented adoption. Therefore, it's important that whatever we build must be simple, readable, and writable.

By building out a rich language of simple Types, we get the building blocks to describe our API models with, and giving us two distinct concepts within our schema space - Types (describing the "What") and Models (describing the structure).

Let's define those a little more formally:

Types

Types represent a single atom of information - a set of shared business concepts used to exchange information - such as FirstName, LastName, CustomerId, DateOfBirth, etc. We've found that once defined, these don't change very frequently.

Types are scalar (attribute-free), single purpose, and seldom change, making them good candidates for sharing. Types are owned and curated collectively, and while (at the beginning) new terms emerge fairly frequently, changes to definitions are less common.

Models

Models are owned by individual systems (the ones that produce the model), and evolve rapidly. Composed of types, they are reshaped, tweaked, with information added and removed frequently - changing with pace as teams ship and refactor functionality. Models describe their attributes using types from the shared taxonomy.

Having introduced these two key building blocks, let talk about the tooling we built to support this idea.

Using Taxi to describe, and Vyne to discover

We built Taxi to address the semantic gap in the schema toolchain - a way to build a semantic taxonomy, and apply it to APIs.

Taxi can work either as a stand-alone API schema, or to decorate existing API Schemas, overlaying semantic context. This means you don't have to throw away all your swagger, you can just mix in some taxi.

Taxi's goals are human readability, descriptiveness, and extensibility. You can write Taxi by hand (unlike Swagger), or generate it from code. Taxi is open-source, type-safe and functionally rich.

Because it's a custom built language, Taxi is much easier to read than Swagger or RAML, which have been shoe-horned into JSON and YAML.

Taxi's syntax borrows heavily from languages like Typescript and Kotlin, which have gained adoption in large part because they're designed to be approachable. We think this is a big difference against other languages in this space, such as JSON-LD, OWL or RDF, which have a much higher barrier-to-entry.

Let's explore how adding some semantic sugar to our API might look.

First, let's define some Types and Models:

type FirstName inherits String
type LastName inherits String
type CustomerId inherits Int
type EmailAddress inherits String
type PrimaryEmailAddress inherits EmailAddress

model Customer {
  firstName : FirstName
  lastName : LastName
  email : PrimaryEmailAddress
  secondaryEmail : EmailAddress
  customerId : CustomerId	
}

And finally, a microservice that's using these:

service CustomerService {
  @HttpOperation(method="GET", url="http://customers/{id}")
  operation getCustomer(id: CustomerId):Customer
}

Given this description, it quickly becomes apparent that if I know a CustomerId, I can get a Customer. And, if I have a Customer, I have access to a bunch of information about them, like their FirstName, and PrimaryEmailAddress.

At this point, the data is sufficiently described that someone can ask for data, agnostic of the service providing it, or the shape it comes in.

For example, as a consumer of data, I could simply ask it something like:

given {
  id : CustomerId = 123
} find {
  name : FirstName
  emails: {
    primary: PrimaryEmailAddress
  }
}

As a consumer request, I've outlined both the semantic contract, and the structural contract I'd like satisfied here. However, I haven't talked about services at all - as a consumer, they're not really of concern to me.

There's enough information for a broker to leverage this, and invoke the correct service to satisfy my request.

Or, if I need my data in a different structure, I can simply ask:

given {
  customerId: CustomerId = 123
} find {
  name: FirstName + ' ' + LastName // Taxi supports basic operations
  contactDetails : {
    preferredEmail : PrimaryEmailAddress
    // allEmails would contain both "email" and "secondaryEmail", since they're both of type EmailAddress
    allEmails : EmailAddress[] 
  }
}

It's entirely up to the consumer to determine the shape of the data they want.

Since we've decoupled the structure from the content, there's enough information for a broker to leverage find and construct the object, without having to maintain a manual mapping layer for every attribute.

By describing both structure and content in the schema, there's enough information for a broker to find and construct an object, without having to maintain a mapping for every attribute.

This is where Vyne comes in. Vyne is our discovery engine - capable of understanding semantic schemas, and leveraging that information to automatically discover data.

Inter-service orchestration

Since our services now have a shared language for describing inputs and outputs (decoupled from structure), we can even leverage this to push inter-service orchestration up to Vyne.

Let's add another service into the mix:

type AcceptsMarketingEmails inherits Boolean
type AllowsCookieTracking inherits Boolean

model MarketingPreferences {
  emailAddress : EmailAddress
  cookies : AllowsCookieTracking
  marketingEmails : AcceptsMarketingEmails
}

service MarketingService {
  @HttpOperation(method="GET", url="http://marketingPreferences/{emailAddress}")
  operation getMarketingPreferences(emailAddress:PrimaryEmailAddress):MarketingPreferences
}

We now have a separate producer microservice that's exposing information about marketing preferences.

As a consumer, I can request data, agnostic of where it's coming from:

given {
  id : CustomerId = 123
} find {
  // Provided by our original CustomerService
  name : FirstName 
  
  // Provided by our original CustomerService
  emailAddress : PrimaryEmailAddress 
  
  // Provided by the new MarketingService
  canSendMarketingEmails : AcceptsMarketingEmails 
}

There's enough breadcrumbs to build a path:

Original CustomerId -> CustomerRecord -> PrimaryEmailAddress -> MarketingPreferences

// TODO : Replace the above with a lineage screenshot from Vyne.

We're able to see here that Vyne was able to bridge multiple services, automatically passing data from one to the next.

Summary

Structure and Semantics are two different types of contracts, and most API schemas at the moment fail to model semantics in a meaningful way.

By creating a taxonomy of shared terms, and overlaying this taxonomy onto our schemas, we have enough information for tools such as Vyne to perform rich, complex data discovery operations.

Finally, by decoupling consumers from both producer services and structural contracts, the producers are free to evolve and change at will, without forcing consumers to upgrade.

If you'd like to learn more about Vyne, please get in touch - I'd love to hear from you.

posts.custom_excerpt: In this post, we'll explore how by adding a tiny bit more metadata to our APIs, we can offload all the integration work to a broker, who can do all the information gathering for us - like a conceirge in a classy hotel.

posts.title: Uniting similar data from multiple sources
posts.mobiledoc: {"version":"0.3.1","atoms":[],"cards":[["markdown",{"markdown":"There’s plenty of legitimate cases where your company could have ended up with multiple services providing what is essentially the same type of data. Possibly it’s as simple as a postcode resolution service, or it could be there’s a few Customer databases floating around. It’d be far too convenient for us for these sources to have stored exactly the same data, using exactly the same representation. Even so, the content they contain almost certainly will have commonalities. In the case of Customer data, you definitely wouldn’t be surprised to find a first name, last name and email address being represented in each system. However, the way these fields are described may vary wildly, and you can’t help it if a developer long ago decided to label their last name property as `frequently_inherited_name`. Regardless, the content of that field is equivalent to your last name, surname or family name fields which are present in the other Customer data sets. Having systems that store and structure data in different ways is a Good Thing - we want our systems to be able to evolve independently, rather than conform to a rigid shared model. After all, you can’t force standardisation, without removing the ability for teams to evolve independently - and that’s not a tradeoff worth making. What’s important is that there’s a common concept being represented, such as a Customer, an Order, or a Product. Once our data scene has been set in this way, sooner or later someone in the business will realise that there’s some value to be gained by being able to query that spread out data in a consistent way. That’s the Chameleon pattern in action."}],["hr",{}],["markdown",{"markdown":"### Where does this happen? This is extremely common. Here’s a few examples that you might recognise: * Your company may have grown up with independent divisions which have evolved separately and built their own versions of things * Through success and good fortune, you’ve acquired a bunch of related littler companies, that each came with their own unique IT infrastructure. * You’re using multiple providers for the same type of service (such as payments) * You’re using multiple vendors for the same type of product (perhaps in your supply chain) * You’ve started adopting microservices, and found that you’ve got duplicate services rearing their heads all over the place! * It’s come time to deal with that dilapidated legacy system, and you’d sooner walk on hot ashes than do a big bang cutover To handle these scenarios, typically we see a couple of different patterns implemented. #### 1. Consumers aggregate data themselves The consuming system queries all providers separately and manually combines them. posts.html:
There’s plenty of legitimate cases where your company could have ended up with multiple services providing what is essentially the same type of data. Possibly it’s as simple as a postcode resolution service, or it could be there’s a few Customer databases floating around. It’d be far too convenient for us for these sources to have stored exactly the same data, using exactly the same representation. Even so, the content they contain almost certainly will have commonalities.

In the case of Customer data, you definitely wouldn’t be surprised to find a first name, last name and email address being represented in each system. However, the way these fields are described may vary wildly, and you can’t help it if a developer long ago decided to label their last name property as frequently_inherited_name.

Regardless, the content of that field is equivalent to your last name, surname or family name fields which are present in the other Customer data sets.

Having systems that store and structure data in different ways is a Good Thing - we want our systems to be able to evolve independently, rather than conform to a rigid shared model. After all, you can’t force standardisation, without removing the ability for teams to evolve independently - and that’s not a tradeoff worth making.

What’s important is that there’s a common concept being represented, such as a Customer, an Order, or a Product.

Once our data scene has been set in this way, sooner or later someone in the business will realise that there’s some value to be gained by being able to query that spread out data in a consistent way. That’s the Chameleon pattern in action.

Where does this happen?

This is extremely common. Here’s a few examples that you might recognise:

  • Your company may have grown up with independent divisions which have evolved separately and built their own versions of things
  • Through success and good fortune, you’ve acquired a bunch of related littler companies, that each came with their own unique IT infrastructure.
  • You’re using multiple providers for the same type of service (such as payments)
  • You’re using multiple vendors for the same type of product (perhaps in your supply chain)
  • You’ve started adopting microservices, and found that you’ve got duplicate services rearing their heads all over the place!
  • It’s come time to deal with that dilapidated legacy system, and you’d sooner walk on hot ashes than do a big bang cutover

To handle these scenarios, typically we see a couple of different patterns implemented.

1. Consumers aggregate data themselves

The consuming system queries all providers separately and manually combines them.

If multiple systems need to consume the same data, each needs to build the same integrations with the source systems, and implement the same aggregation and reshaping code to convert the source data to something that’s useful to it.

This is great for developers who get paid per line of code.

2. Our data providers expose canonical models

To save every consumer from the burden of integrating and reshaping the diverse data formats provided by source systems, you might think of forcing each provider to expose a canonical version of the data.

This helps our Super App developers to an extent, they still have to call out to every system, but at least the data is in the same format. The downside is that the data has to be in the same format! Both of our providers need to agree what a common definition of a customer model is. Cue the politics.

3. Our data is extracted to a separate store

An ETL pipeline is built to extract data from the providers and store it in a Data Lake or Data Warehouse in a normalized format

This solves the problem of each Super App that comes along having to solve the same problem of fetching and aggregating data from multiple sources, but it does bring with it some important restrictions.

The data is now coupled to the canonical model which has been enforced by the ETL pipeline and Data Warehouse. Getting functionality changes through to our Super App is now an IT project involving at least 3 teams (Source system, data pipeline and super app). This clearly makes the lead time of feature requests an immediate challenge.

Depending on your perspective of life as a data engineer, this is either fantastic or very frustrating. As the team building the pipelines and warehouse, you’re involved in all the action, but you’re not responsible for any end user functionality - and therefore the delivery pressure.

How Vyne does it

Vyne approaches this problem differently by providing a flexible data layer for consumers to query data. It automatically aggregates and reshapes the source data based on the needs of the consumer, saving you a huge amount of time typically spent on integrating with other systems and transforming data.

By using our open source data language, Taxi, we define a shared language of terms which can be used to describe the data provided by each individual system. This helps us to focus on the content of what systems are providing, rather than the format and structure of their data.

The result for our Super App is that by querying via Vyne, it’s not limited to the data which can be provided by the data pipeline layer. It also doesn’t have to worry about managing individual integrations with each provider. We get the best of both worlds!

As a bonus, when the providers inevitably change, Vyne adapts with them to ensure minimal impact to our Super App and other consumers. We don’t have to wait for negotiations about our canonical model, or for our data pipeline team to complete work to propagate changes. When our data providers change, we can immediately change with them. Dare I say it, but that sounds a little bit agile.

Sound familiar? Get in touch at hello@vyne.co for a chat.

This is part of the Vyne Blueprint series where we examine common data patterns that exist in tech stacks today and review some of the existing architectures for solving them. We'll then take a look at what a better option would be with the use of Vyne and Taxi.

Vyne is an automated data discovery tool that connects, secures and manages the data being provided by systems within your organisation. It adapts to your tech landscape as you change your systems, letting your move forward with confidence. It's powered by Taxi, our open source language for data that let's you create a rich description of the data in your ecosystem. By encoding the relationships between your data in a non proprietary and system agnostic way you can understand your organisations data in whole new way.

A common data pattern is for the same type of data to exist in different formats from multiple providers. It's the same thing but can look a bit different just like a Chameleon.

In this post, we're going to compare some familiar solutions and what Vyne offers as a federated data discovery platform.
